Unlock your healthiest self in 2025: How much daily walking is really enough? - Irish Star
summary:
How Much You Should Walk Every Day to Be Your Healthiest Self

Published: Not specified Source: Irish Star

The article discusses how many steps one should aim to walk each day to maintain good health, especially as people set their resolutions for the New Year. It emphasizes that a target of 10,000 steps, or about four to five miles, is commonly recommended for health benefits.

  • The ideal walking distance depends on various personal factors like weight, health goals, fitness level, and existing conditions.
  • It's advisable for beginners to start slowly with shorter distances and to gradually increase their walking as they become comfortable.
  • Walking more can assist with weight loss; burning approximately 300 to 400 calories daily can lead to losing one pound per week if combined with a balanced diet.
  • Distributing walking throughout the day can make the goal more achievable, such as taking brisk walks at different times rather than all at once.
  • Having a walking companion can motivate individuals to reach their daily goals while enjoying each other's company.
"With a target of 10,000 steps a day, you can burn approximately 300 to 400 calories, leading to potential weight loss over time."

In conclusion, walking is a simple, cost-effective way to improve health and well-being, making it an ideal New Year's resolution.
newTitle: How Much You Should Walk Every Day to Be Your Healthiest Self

Rotis made on direct flame can cause cancer? Here's what experts have to say - Deccan Herald
summary:
Rotis made on direct flame can cause cancer? Here's what experts have to say

Published: 31 December 2024, 17:47 IST

Rotis are a staple in Indian households, but studies suggest that cooking them over a direct flame may pose health risks, potentially leading to cancer. Experts weigh in on the risks associated with this cooking method.

  • Cooking rotis involves placing dough on a hot pan followed by direct exposure to gas flames for puffing.
  • Research indicates that emissions from natural gas stoves are linked to health issues such as cancer and heart disease.
  • Pyrolysis during the cooking process may create carcinogenic compounds.
  • Experts note that harmful compounds like PAHs and HCAs are not likely produced unless cooking exceeds 15 minutes.
  • A well-ventilated kitchen and clean stove can mitigate health risks.
“Cancer risks of cooking roti on a gas hob have been overplayed so don’t panic,” said nutritionist Pallavi Pinge.

In conclusion, while there are potential risks, proper cooking methods and ventilation can reduce health concerns significantly.
newTitle: Rotis Made on Direct Flame: Cancer Risks and Expert Insights

title: 10 diet types you must adopt in 2025 for a healthy heart - The Times of India
summary:
10 Diet Types You Must Adopt in 2025 for a Healthy Heart

Publication Date: Dec 31, 2024 | Source: TimesOfIndia.com

As we approach 2025, adopting heart-friendly diets will be crucial for maintaining cardiovascular health, reducing inflammation, lowering cholesterol, and promoting longevity.

  • Mediterranean diet: Reduces heart disease risk by promoting healthy cholesterol.
  • DASH Diet: Aims to lower blood pressure by focusing on fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
  • Paleo diet: Emphasizes whole foods like lean meats and fruits while avoiding processed foods.
  • Low-carb, high-fiber diet: Helps keep blood sugar low and reduces heart disease risk.
  • Flexitarian diet: Primarily plant-based but allows occasional meat consumption.
  • Anti-inflammatory diet: Incorporates foods that reduce chronic inflammation.
  • Low-sodium diet: Focuses on fresh foods and limits high-sodium processed products.
  • Whole-food, plant-based diet: Focuses on whole foods while eliminating processed options.
  • Plant-based diet: Rich in fiber and antioxidants, protecting heart health.
  • Intermittent fasting: May lower blood pressure and cholesterol through a pattern of eating.
“These diets reduce inflammation, decrease cholesterol, and usually preserve the functionality of the heart.”

Adopting these diets in 2025 could significantly enhance heart health and overall well-being.
newTitle: 10 Diet Types You Must Adopt in 2025 for a Healthy Heart

title: 5 warning signs of Vitamin B12 deficiency in your feet you shouldn't ignore - The Times of India
summary:
5 Warning Signs of Vitamin B12 Deficiency in Your Feet

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: Times of India

The symptoms of Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to nerve damage and affect daily life. It's essential to recognize early signs to prevent irreversible damage.

  • Numbness and tingling in feet
  • Burning sensation in extremities
  • Difficulty walking or loss of balance
  • Pale or yellowish skin on feet
  • Persistent cold feet
“According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), peripheral neuropathy caused by B12 deficiency can become irreversible if untreated.”

Recognizing these signs early can help in addressing Vitamin B12 deficiency and maintaining overall nerve health.
newTitle: 5 Warning Signs of Vitamin B12 Deficiency in Your Feet

5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science - EatingWell
summary:
5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

Many people wish to live long and healthy lives. While the fountain of youth has yet to be found, certain dietary and lifestyle choices can help keep your ticker ticking and your body working for a long time. Among these choices, coffee consumption has shown significant health benefits that may contribute to longevity.

  • May Help Manage a Healthy Weight: Caffeine intake can promote reductions in body fat and weight.
  • May Support Heart Health: Drinking 3 to 5 cups of coffee per day may reduce the risk of heart disease by 15%.
  • May Reduce Risk of Type 2 Diabetes: Coffee drinking is linked to a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
  • May Help Protect from Certain Cancers: Coffee may reduce the risk of liver and endometrial cancers.
  • May Improve Cognitive Function and Mood: Caffeine has been shown to enhance cognitive function and may lower the risk of depression.
“Who doesn't want to live a long and healthy life? While there is no guarantee, there are some things you can do that may help keep that inevitable occurrence from happening too soon.”

The evidence suggests that moderate coffee consumption can provide several health benefits, potentially helping to prolong life.
newTitle: 5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science

title: Woman diagnosed with 'most painful condition known to medicine' shares unexpected first symptom - UNILAD
summary:
Australian Woman Shares Initial Symptom of Severe Pain Condition

Published on December 31, 2022 by UNILAD

An Australian woman, Emily Morton, opened up about her diagnosis of atypical trigeminal neuralgia, described as the 'world's most painful condition', and the unexpected initial symptom of pain in her teeth.

  • Emily, from Adelaide, first noticed pain in her teeth in 2022.
  • Despite dental visits, no cause for the pain was found, which later spread to her entire face.
  • She experiences pain all over her body, unlike typical trigeminal neuralgia, which affects one side of the face.
  • Emily's condition has led to financial strain, with her family spending thousands on treatments and tests.
  • A new surgery offers some hope but comes with a high cost, leading to a GoFundMe page set up for Emily's treatment.
“It feels like a race against time to find out why. The condition has taken everything from me.”

Emily continues to search for treatment options while advocating for better support for those with invisible illnesses.
newTitle: Australian Woman Shares Initial Symptom of Severe Pain Condition

title: As Ozempic takes over weight loss conversation in 2024, find out what the New Year may bring for its development and accessibility - The Indian Express
summary:
As Ozempic takes over weight loss conversation in 2024, find out what the New Year may bring for its development and accessibility

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Indian Express

The article discusses the growing popularity of Ozempic and other GLP-1 receptor agonists as weight loss solutions in 2024. Originally intended for diabetes management, they have sparked debates about ethics, accessibility, and long-term health effects.

  • Ozempic has gained traction for effective weight loss, showing a 15–20% reduction compared to lifestyle changes.
  • Key factors for normalization include celebrity endorsements and increased public awareness.
  • Concerns about high costs and accessibility are highlighted, with potential solutions suggested.
  • Health risks associated with long-term use include gastrointestinal issues and pancreatitis.
“While GLP-1 agonists offer a promising solution for weight loss, their long-term effects, accessibility, and ethical use require careful regulation.” - Dr. Jagadish Hiremath

The article concludes that while GLP-1 agonists like Ozempic present new opportunities for weight management, careful consideration of their implications and accessibility will be essential moving forward.
newTitle: Ozempic's Rise in Weight Loss Conversations and Future Outlook

summary:
CDC on High Alert as Bird Flu Cases Rise in the US: Is the H5N1 Virus Showing Pandemic Red Flags?

Last Updated: 31 December, 2024 09:59 AM GMT
Source: The Feed

Bird flu cases are on the rise in the U.S., and the CDC is on high alert. With 66 confirmed human cases so far, officials are watching closely for signs that the virus could mutate and spread more easily between people, raising concerns about a potential pandemic.

  • The CDC is monitoring an increase in bird flu cases, especially the H5N1 strain.
  • 66 confirmed human cases have been reported.
  • CDC is looking for signs of potential mutations and human transmission.
  • A patient in Louisiana was hospitalized with a mutated virus.
  • Public risk remains low, with no transmission from the Louisiana patient reported.
A spokesperson from the CDC mentioned, "We are looking for clusters of influenza A(H5N1) human cases, which could indicate that the virus is better able to spread."

The CDC will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates to prevent the spread of the virus.

title: Microplastic Concentrations In The Human Body Linked To Multiple Tissue Lesions - IFLScience
summary:
Microplastic Concentrations in the Human Body Linked to Multiple Tissue Lesions

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: IFLScience

A new metadata analysis into the presence of microplastic concentrations in humans has highlighted multiple links with tissue damage and other health conditions.

  • Microplastics have been detected in multiple human systems including respiratory, digestive, and reproductive organs.
  • Inhalation is identified as the primary route for MNP entry into the body.
  • Children and elderly individuals are identified as being more susceptible to MNP exposure.
  • MNPs are suggested to cause various health issues including oxidative stress and potential neurodegenerative diseases.
  • Notable correlations exist between MNP concentrations and diseases such as cancer and inflammatory bowel disease.
“MNPs with different types, shapes and sizes have been detected in various human systems. Notably, the occurrence of MNPs is markedly correlated with corresponding lesions and diseases, which is the key evidence that MNPs harm human health.”

The findings highlight the urgent need for more research into the characterization and effects of microplastics in human health.
newTitle: Microplastic Concentrations in the Human Body Linked to Multiple Tissue Lesions

title: GMC Anantnag creates history, performs 50 LBB-A Pacing procedures under C-arm - Greater Kashmir
summary:
GMC Anantnag creates history, performs 50 LBB-A Pacing procedures under C-arm

Date: December 31, 2024 | Source: Greater Kashmir

Government Medical College (GMC) Anantnag has successfully performed 50 cases of Left Bundle Branch Area (LBB-A) pacing under C-arm in just four months, marking a significant achievement in cardiac care without electrophysiology (EP) backup.

  • The achievement was led by Principal GMC Anantnag, Professor. Dr. Rukhsana Najeeb, and a dedicated cardiology team.
  • Initially started in September 2024, this innovative procedure transitions from conventional pacemaker implantation.
  • The success rate of the procedures reached 95%, with no reported mortality.
“This shows innovation, perseverance, and commitment to advancing cardiac care in a resource-constrained setting,” said Dr. Najeeb.
“Dr. Najeeb congratulated the cardiology team on this historic accomplishment and reiterated her commitment to elevating GMC Anantnag to one of the top medical institutions in the country.”
newTitle: GMC Anantnag Achieves Milestone with 50 LBB-A Pacing Procedures

title: Shortage of hepatitis B vaccine continues to plague Kerala’s private hospitals - The Hindu
summary:
Shortage of Hepatitis B Vaccine Continues to Plague Kerala’s Private Hospitals

Published Date: December 31, 2024
Source: IST

Private hospitals in Kerala are facing an alarming shortage of hepatitis B vaccines, affecting both new staff and at-risk patients.

  • The hepatitis B virus is transmitted during birth and through contact with infected blood or fluids.
  • Patients undergoing dialysis are at an extremely high risk and require vaccination for protection.
  • Unvaccinated individuals exposed to the virus need hepatitis B immunoglobulin treatment, which can be expensive.
  • Newborns of infected mothers and newly recruited healthcare staff are severely impacted.
  • The vaccine supply is expected to improve, but delays persist, leaving hospitals struggling.
  • Manufacturers have reduced production due to low profit margins and reported shortages of raw materials.
  • Bivalent vaccines, such as twinrix, are available, providing combined protection against hepatitis A and B.
  • Public health experts emphasize the need for more vaccine options amid frequent hepatitis A outbreaks in the state.
“If Indian manufacturers can come up with a cost-effective bivalent vaccine, the people will be protected from two hepatitis viruses for life.”

The ongoing shortage of the hepatitis B vaccine poses serious health risks, urging for immediate attention from manufacturers and health authorities.
newTitle: Shortage of Hepatitis B Vaccine Continues in Kerala's Private Hospitals

Woman who lost 20 kilos, shares 8 effective tips for weight loss: ‘Chew everything thoroughly’ - Hindustan Times
summary:
Woman Shares 8 Effective Tips for Weight Loss After Losing 20 Kilos

Dec 31, 2024 by Zarafshan Shiraz

Pritika Srinivasan, a CA and nutritionist, shares her personal journey of losing 20 kilos, emphasizing that weight loss is about health and confidence, not just numbers on a scale. She highlights eight practical strategies that helped her achieve her weight loss goals.

  • 1. Walk up and down the stairs for 10 minutes daily.
  • 2. Don't eat extra when you are full; practice mindfulness to avoid binge eating.
  • 3. Say NO to sugar to prevent health issues.
  • 4. Eat home-made food to control ingredients and avoid hidden calories.
  • 5. Stop eating oily and junk food that increase health risks.
  • 6. Include more protein in your diet for satiety and muscle support.
  • 7. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity every day.
  • 8. Chew everything thoroughly to promote better eating habits.
“Protein and fiber help you feel fuller for longer, reducing the chances of overeating or making unhealthy food choices,” said Dr Pramod Tripathi.

These strategies are not only effective for weight loss but also promote overall health and well-being. Always consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice.
newTitle: Woman Shares 8 Effective Tips for Weight Loss After Losing 20 Kilos

title: Norovirus cases rising in the US: How it spreads, what precautions can be taken - The Indian Express
summary:
Norovirus cases rising in the US: How it spreads, what precautions can be taken

Publication Date: December 2023 | Source: The New York Times

The stomach infection norovirus is causing concern in the United States, with over 90 cases reported in the first week of December, primarily linked to raw oysters.

  • At least 80 people became ill after consuming contaminated raw oysters from a restaurant event in Los Angeles.
  • These oysters were sourced from British Columbia and had been distributed across 14 US states before recall.
  • Norovirus is highly contagious and spreads through contaminated food, water, and surfaces.
  • Symptoms include vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain, with severe cases leading to dehydration.
  • Precautions include frequent handwashing and cleaning surfaces with hypochlorite solutions to prevent spread.
  • The illness is self-limiting, typically lasting two to three days without vaccines available.
“Norovirus infection is associated with intestinal inflammation, malnutrition and may cause long-term morbidity.” - WHO

The rise in norovirus cases poses a serious public health concern, necessitating awareness and strict hygiene practices to curb its spread.
newTitle: Norovirus Outbreak in the US: Understanding the Causes and Precautions

Health authorities in Victoria, Australia, have issued a warning following the identification of a human case of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus.

  • First human case of JE virus reported in Victoria this summer.
  • Health officials advise precautions against mosquito bites.
  • The JE virus can lead to severe illness, including brain infections.
  • Children and the elderly are at higher risk of severe illness.
"The risk of mosquito-borne diseases remains high in the coming weeks. Taking measures to avoid mosquito bites is critical to protect against infections." - Christian McGrath, Acting Chief Health Officer

This health alert underscores the importance of public awareness and preventive measures as Australia enters the mosquito season.

Introduction

As we celebrate the arrival of 2025, many of us may feel the effects of overindulgence during New Year's celebrations. A gentle detox can help reset the body and mind for the year ahead.

title: Polio Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries Battling A Resurgence Of The Disease - TheHealthSite
summary:
Polio Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries Battling A Resurgence Of The Disease

Publication Date: 2024

Source: The Health Site

The year 2024 saw a resurgence of the polio virus in many countries, affecting both sewage and water systems as well as human populations. This article reviews the countries impacted by this outbreak.

Key Points

  • Pakistan: Three cases of wild poliovirus (WPV1) reported along with environmental samples.
  • Afghanistan: Five WPV1 cases reported alongside multiple positive environmental samples.
  • Nigeria: Notable concern with 30 cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2).
  • Angola, Benin, Guinea: Each recorded one case of cVDPV2.
  • Indonesia: At least four cases of cVDPV2 confirmed.
  • Kenya: Detected one positive environmental sample for cVDPV2.
  • Niger: Confirmed one case of cVDPV2 and two positive environmental samples.
  • Somalia: Recorded two positive environmental samples for cVDPV2.
  • Gaza Strip: A new case of variant polio virus reported in a 10-month-old baby, leading to a vaccination drive by the UN.

Symptoms Of Polio

Symptoms of polio can be mild or severe, with some cases leading to paralysis or respiratory failure, highlighting the seriousness of the virus.

Conclusion

The resurgence of polio in 2024 poses serious public health challenges worldwide, necessitating heightened vigilance and vaccination efforts.
newTitle: Polio Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries Battling A Resurgence Of The Disease

title: Need A Break From Work Stress? Try These 5 10-Minute Hacks And Feel Good Instantly - HerZindagi English
summary:
Need A Break From Work Stress? Try These 5 10-Minute Hacks And Feel Good Instantly

Publication Date: Not specified Source: HerZindagi

In today's fast-paced world, workplace stress is increasingly common, with many professionals experiencing mental health challenges. The article provides quick 10-minute mental health hacks to help alleviate stress and improve overall well-being.

  • Mindful breathing: Start your day with 10 minutes of mindful breathing techniques like Anulom-Vilom and Pranayama.
  • Desk yoga: Perform simple stretches at your desk to relieve physical strain.
  • Gratitude journaling: Write down three things you're thankful for to lower stress and boost positivity.
  • 20-20-20 rule: To combat screen fatigue, take breaks every 20 minutes to focus on something 20 feet away for 20 seconds.
  • Ayurvedic brews: Replace coffee breaks with calming herbal teas to combat stress.
Sakshi Shah, Founder of GoodLives, emphasizes, “Small, regular actions can sometimes have a significant impact. Incorporating 10-minute mental health exercises into daily life might have a profound impact on time-pressed Indian professionals.”

These simple practices can significantly enhance mental wellness among busy professionals.
newTitle: Quick 10-Minute Hacks to Alleviate Workplace Stress
